text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time sorry that was
kind of forceful and it's time for an
album review christian mistress
possession these guys are a hard rock
band from olympia washington you can
call it metal if you want to use the
n-word and this is their sophomore LP
it's their debut album for relapse
records and these guys don't exactly
play a new sound of metal a new style of
metal their music kind of rejects all of
the harsh and abrasive and overly
aggressive sounds that the genre has
evolved into over the years if you want
a more simple explanation it's more like
what would happen if metal as a genre
had stopped evolving around 1982 the
thing is these guys managed to
incorporate sounds from metal music
before that decade - yeah they have the
really driving hyper melodic and
accessible sounds of like Judas Priest
and Iron Maiden but also they've got
that really heavy
brooding darkness of groups like Black
Sabbath there's a little bit of rush in
there too and and rush is a very minor
minor part of this album's recipe and
it's only a comparison that I make
because of the vocals it's not like
there are any insane or technical
progressive rock time signature changes
on this thing it's just the voice of
frontwoman Christine Davis she's got a
really smoky dramatic vocal delivery and
it's got a very very light raspy nough
stew it - and the cadence of her voice
reminds me a little bit of russia's
Geddy Lee I do think it's kind of an
unintended similarity though now
sometimes on this LP Davis is really not
as aggressive as I would expect a metal
vocalist to be aggression is not really
her strong point but it's not really
something I think she emphasis
anyway her voice is much better suited
for bringing feelings of darkness and
enchantment and tortured miss she does
have some nice versatility though there
are spots on here like the track
pentagram and crucifix where she's
pretty forceful and on the flip side she
can come off very dreary and forlorn
like on the title track here now even
though the vocals are sort of not going
to jump out of the shadows and tear your
face off like a starving Wolverine this
album is definitely no slouch it's not a
wimp some of these tracks have a lot of
momentum to them like the song over and
over the opener
lots of Drive lots of punch on that song
hard riffs a very fast beat - and the
song black - gold has kind of the pedal
to the metal - it feels even more
intense with these harmonized guitar
leads kind of galloping across the
groove but there are other spots on here
maybe those are my favourites where
things are slower much more brooding
heavier I guess you could say the title
track feels that way to me that song to
me just feels like pagan rituals
pentagram dry out on the ground and
blood candles everywhere people are
wearing cloaks or maybe it's even more
like a swamp and Davises vocals kind of
like the the fog creeping out over the
water with all these Tony Iommi guitar
leads just wailing over the music I mean
for a group that pretty much sticks to
one style of rock there's a lot of
variety here in in volume and tempo and
mood the band even makes sure to change
up its song structures as the album
progresses the opening track is just
really hard hitting just over two
minutes kind of wham bam thank you man
lots of energy as the album goes on the
songs are getting longer and by the end
of this thing lots of changes lots of
different parts acoustic interludes that
are really funky and and beautiful and
build up into these heavy and feminine
get our leads that sing out epically
into the Starkist night so yeah the
tracks kind of get
little more progressive as the album
continues you can see that I like this
album but I still have to admit that
this band is doing nothing new
stylistically you know if you're on the
hunt for a hot new band with a hot new
sound or if music that kind of lives in
the past usually makes you roll your
eyes you're probably not going to enjoy
this but then again there are some
groups who are heavily influenced by
bands or musicians from the past but
still managed to drum up their own style
or sound in a genre that most people
thought was just done innovating the
metal band ghost kind of comes to mind
and you know if you don't think
Christian mistress is is putting their
own spin on this style of old-school
metal then I would argue they are at
least very close to doing so I think
this album still manages to be really
fun really energetic and catchy and
really strong musically like the
instrumental bridge on the track
pentagram and crucifix is so intense
it's camping yes oh that and the way the
tempo slows down on the track conviction
it creates a really passionate break in
the song and I really love the Sinister
guitar riffs that open up the song the
way beyond between the great guitar
solos and the pulsating riffs the fiery
leads the bass lines that that hit the
groove in all the right places the
vocals and and the very good drumming I
think Christian mistress is an
old-school metal machine they're hardly
amateurs who are just trying to copy for
me they're more like connoisseurs trying
to rekindle
trying to find a lost connection I
really think these guys were just faced
with the unfortunate situation of being
born too late so bluntly feeling the
light eight on this album enjoy the hell
out of it
really fun LP really fun rock album and
yeah what do you guys think of it do you
love it do you hate it why and what
should I review next anthony Fantana
Christian mistress forever
